Dance</a></span></p><p class="css-1xuzukf e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">Graphics by </span><span class="css-1baulvz" itemProp="name"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/tim-wallace" class="css-n8ff4n e1jsehar0">Tim Wallace</a></span> and <span class="css-1baulvz last-byline" itemProp="name"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/zach-levitt" class="css-n8ff4n e1jsehar0">Zach Levitt</a></span></p><div id="enhanced-byline" class="css-8atqhb"><p class="css-m7kxl4 e1wtpvyy0">Gabriel J.X. Dance traveled to Texas and North Dakota, interviewed Bitcoin miners, energy experts, scientists and politicians and analyzed thousands of records detailing mining operations for this story. <a rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://www.nytimes.com/tips?module=inline" title="" class="css-13m58p7">Send tips</a>.</p></div></div></div><div data-testid="reading-time-module" class="css-8atqhb"><ul class="css-1cgskve epjyd6m3"><li class="css-ccw2r3 epjyd6m2"><time dateTime="2023-04-11T17:24:32-04:00" class="css-qr5h11 e16638kd2"><span class="css-1sbuyqj e16638kd3">Published <!-- -->April 9, 2023</span><span class="css-233int e16638kd4">Updated <!-- -->April 11, 2023</span></time></li></ul></div></div></div></div><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div><figure class="margins-h css-1vfijp3"><figcaption class="css-5soref"><div class="audioFigureHeading"><h3 class="css-m1fye1">Listen to This Article</h3></div></figcaption><div class="css-f4hvxb"><div><script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"http://schema.org","@type":"AudioObject","@id":"https://static.nytimes.com/podcasts/2023/04/11/business/10bitcoin-audio/230409-bitcoin-real-world-costs-nyt-audm.mp3","description":"","name":"Listen to This Article","contentUrl":"https://static.nytimes.com/podcasts/2023/04/11/business/10bitcoin-audio/230409-bitcoin-real-world-costs-nyt-audm.mp3","duration":"PT1.663S"}</script></div></div></figure></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Texas was gasping for electricity. Winter Storm Uri had knocked out power plants across the state, leaving tens of thousands of homes in icy darkness. By the end of Feb. 14, 2021, nearly 40 people had died, some from the freezing cold.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Meanwhile, in the husk of a onetime aluminum smelting plant an hour outside of Austin, row upon row of computers were using enough electricity to power about 6,500 homes as they raced to earn Bitcoin, the world’s largest cryptocurrency.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The computers were performing trillions of calculations per second, hunting for an elusive combination of numbers that Bitcoin’s algorithm would accept. About every 10 minutes, a computer somewhere guesses correctly and wins a small number of Bitcoins worth, in recent weeks, about $170,000. Anyone can try, but to make a business of it can require as much electricity as a small city.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In Texas, the computers kept running until just after midnight. Then the state’s power grid operator ordered them shut off, under an agreement that allowed it to do so if the system was about to fail. In return, it began paying the Bitcoin company, Bitdeer, an average of $175,000 an hour to keep the computers offline. Over the next four days, Bitdeer would make more than $18 million for not operating, from fees ultimately paid by Texans who had endured the storm.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The New York Times has identified 34 such large-scale operations, known as Bitcoin mines, in the United States, all putting immense pressure on the power grid and most finding novel ways to profit from doing so. Their operations can create costs — including higher electricity bills and enormous carbon pollution — for everyone around them, most of whom have nothing to do with Bitcoin.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Until June 2021, most Bitcoin mining was in China. Then it drove out Bitcoin operations, at least for a time, citing their power use among other reasons. The United States quickly became the industry’s global leader.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Since then, precisely how much electricity Bitcoin mines are using in America and their effect on energy markets and the environment have been unclear. The Times, using both public and confidential records as well as the results of studies it commissioned, put the most comprehensive estimates to date on the largest operations’ power use and the ripple effects of their voracious demand.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><section id="households-energy-map" data-id="100000008788712" data-source-id="100000008788712" class="interactive-content interactive-size-scoop css-1fwl6kh"><div class="css-17ih8de interactive-body" data-sourceid="100000008788712">

  NYTG.watch('https://static01.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2022-09-26-bitcoin/97438f878474147d847caed8c8ffbccd6e5dfb4d/_assets/build/js/main.js');
  NYTG.load('https://static01.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2022-09-26-bitcoin/97438f878474147d847caed8c8ffbccd6e5dfb4d/_assets/build/js/freebird.js');

</div><footer id="interactive-footer" class="css-nt2azn interactive-footer"><p data-testid="source" id="interactive-source" class="css-1648plh interactive-source">Sources: Aerial images by Pictometry (Kearney, Neb.) and Nearmap (Dalton, Ga.); drone image by Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times (Rockdale, Texas)</p><p data-testid="credit" id="interactive-credit" class="css-1648plh interactive-credit">undefined</p></footer></section></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">It is as if another New York City’s worth of residences were now drawing on the nation’s power supply, The Times found.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In some areas, this has led prices to surge. In Texas, where 10 of the 34 mines are connected to the state’s grid, the increased demand has caused electric bills for power customers to rise nearly 5 percent, or $1.8 billion per year, according to a simulation performed for The Times by the energy research and consulting firm Wood Mackenzie.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The additional power use across the country also causes as much carbon pollution as adding 3.5 million gas-powered cars to America’s roads, according to an analysis by WattTime, a nonprofit tech company. Many of the Bitcoin operations promote themselves as environmentally friendly and set up in areas rich with renewable energy, but their power needs are far too great to be satisfied by those sources alone. As a result, they have become a boon for the fossil fuel industry: WattTime found that coal and natural gas plants kick in to meet 85 percent of the demand these Bitcoin operations add to their grids.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Their massive energy consumption combined with their ability to shut off almost instantly allows some companies to save money and make money by deftly pulling the levers of U.S. power markets. They can avoid fees charged during peak demand, resell their electricity at a premium when prices spike and even be paid for offering to turn off. Other major energy users, like factories and hospitals, cannot reduce their power use as routinely or dramatically without severe consequences.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In some states, notably New York, Pennsylvania and Texas, Bitcoin operators’ revenue can ultimately come from other power customers. The clearest example is Texas, where Bitcoin companies are paid by the grid operator for promising to quickly power down if necessary to prevent blackouts. In practice, they rarely are asked to shut down and instead earn additional money while doing exactly what they would have been doing anyway: seeking Bitcoin. Five operations have collectively made at least $60 million from that program since 2020, records show.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Several of the companies are being paid through these agreements a majority of the time they operate. Most years, they are asked to turn off for only a few hours, at which point they are paid even more.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The windfall for Bitdeer during Winter Storm Uri came through this program, in exchange for a fraction of the power it typically used. The company did not respond to requests for comment. Another Bitcoin company made tens of millions of dollars reselling electricity during the storm — and ultimately stands to earn as much as $125 million — according to its financial filings, which were previously reported by the <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://techtransparencyproject.cdn.prismic.io/techtransparencyproject/369c5690-7e26-427a-9116-26f46616b45d_Crypto+Texas+Report.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Tech Transparency Project</a>. A third company <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1886015/000121390022007894/fs12022a4_agoradigitalhold.htm" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">told investors</a> that another natural disaster like Uri could be a significant business opportunity.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Ironically, when people are paying the most for their power, or losing it altogether, the miners are making money selling energy back to Texans at rates 100 times what they paid,” said Ed Hirs, who teaches energy economics at the University of Houston and has been critical of the industry.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In interviews and statements, many of the companies said they were no different from other large power users except for their willingness to shut off quickly to benefit the grid. Several objected to the method The Times and WattTime used to estimate their emissions, which calculated the pollution caused by the additional power generated to satisfy the mines’ demand, showing it to overwhelmingly come from fossil fuels.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The companies said this method held them to an unfair standard.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“The analysis cited could be used to attack any industry that consumes power,” said David Fogel, the chief executive of Coinmint, which operates in upstate New York. “I think the entire notion of singling out specific industries like this is unfair.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">But WattTime’s method is the one many energy and climate experts recommend for measuring the environmental effects of increased power use by any industry, particularly one that grows so large so suddenly.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Some in the industry have pushed back against suggestions that it is directly responsible for any environmental harm.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">A May 2022 <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://bitcoinminingcouncil.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/05/Bitcoin_Letter_to_the_Environmental_Protection_Agency.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">letter</a> to the Environmental Protection Agency, signed by many of the biggest companies, said their operations “released” no pollutants. “Bitcoin miners have no emissions whatsoever,” it said. “Associated emissions are a function of electricity generation.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Nic Carter, a partner at a crypto-focused venture capital firm and a<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> </em></strong>prominent Bitcoin advocate who told The Times he was the letter’s primary author, said he was playing a “language game” when he wrote that Bitcoin mining has no emissions. At the time, he said, he felt the industry was being unfairly singled out.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Maybe the more sincere point is like, we’re already fully aware of the emissions associated with utilities generating grid power,” he said.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Many academics who study the energy industry said Bitcoin mining was undoubtedly having significant environmental effects.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“They’re adding hundreds of megawatts of new demand when we already face the need to rapidly cut fossil power,” said Jesse Jenkins, a Princeton professor who studies electrical grid emissions.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“If you care about climate change,” he added, “then that’s a problem.”</p><h2 class="css-9ycfei eoo0vm40" id="link-15e76f24">Flooding Into America</h2><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Bitcoin, conceived in 2008, introduced most of the world to the concept of cryptocurrencies. Instead of trusting banks to track the value of accounts, the system publishes transactions on a public ledger called a blockchain. Proponents said that cutting out middlemen would free people from financial institutions, government oversight and fees.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">So-called mining is a fundamental part of the system: When a computer guesses correctly, it updates the ledger and collects six and a quarter new Bitcoins. Then the guessing game begins again.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Initially, hobbyists could win with personal computers, but as the value of each Bitcoin soared — from under $1,000 in 2017 to above $60,000 in 2021 — mining increasingly became an industrial endeavor. (The price has since dropped and, as of publication, was roughly $28,000.)</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The only way for miners to better their odds is to add computing power, which requires more electricity. But as the number of guesses increases, the algorithm makes the game more difficult. This has created an energy arms race.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The mines’ scale can draw gasps from people in the power industry. A one-megawatt mine consumes more energy each day than a typical U.S. home does in two years. The electricity coursing through a 100-megawatt operation at a given moment could power about half the homes in Cleveland, according to federal data.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><section id="bitcoin-metaphors" data-id="100000008796060" data-source-id="100000008796060" class="interactive-content interactive-size-scoop css-1fwl6kh"><div class="css-17ih8de interactive-body" data-sourceid="100000008796060">

</div></section></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Aspects of the industry have previously been <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://fortune.com/2022/08/13/riot-blockchain-bitcoin-mining-texas-electric-grid-subsidy/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">reported</a> in news articles and <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.whitehouse.gov/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/09-2022-Crypto-Assets-and-Climate-Report.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">government</a> and <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://earthjustice.org/wp-content/uploads/energy_bomb_bitcoin_white_paper_101322.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">nonprofit white papers</a>, including broad estimates of the environmental effects. But The Times cross-referenced financial disclosures, land records and satellite imagery to create the first national accounting of the biggest operations. The analysis includes mines operating at approximately 40 megawatts or higher, although dozens more exist below that threshold.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Of course, other industries, including metals and plastics manufacturing, also require large amounts of electricity, causing pollution and raising power prices. But Bitcoin mines bring significantly fewer jobs, often employing only a few dozen people once construction is complete, and spur less local economic development.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Their financial benefit flows almost exclusively to their owners and operators. In 2021, the year Bitcoin’s price peaked, 20 executives at five publicly traded Bitcoin companies together received nearly $16 million in salary and over $630 million in stock options, records show.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The industry has been less profitable since then, as Bitcoin’s value has dropped and electricity prices have climbed. Two of the largest United States-based companies have filed for bankruptcy. Still, new mines continue to open across the country</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">There are ways to operate a cryptocurrency using far less electricity. Last year, Ethereum, the second-most-popular cryptocurrency, reduced the electricity needed to power the network by more than 99 percent by switching its algorithm. Now it rewards people and trusts them to update the ledger because they are willing to put up their own money as collateral, not because they have spent money to power guessing computers, as Bitcoin does.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">But Bitcoin advocates oppose changing their algorithm, saying that it has proved resistant to attacks for longer and at a greater scale than any other approach. In practice, they say, the more computers making guesses, the safer the network.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><section id="genesis-pyote-card" data-id="100000008839971" data-source-id="100000008839971" class="interactive-content interactive-size-scoop css-1fwl6kh"><div class="css-17ih8de interactive-body" data-sourceid="100000008839971">

</div></section></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">As Bitcoin mining has spread, countries around the world have found that operations strained their power grids. In 2019, China declared the industry “<a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.coindesk.com/markets/2019/04/09/chinas-economic-planning-body-labels-bitcoin-mining-an-undesirable-industry/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">undesirable</a>” and banned it in 2021. Many operations moved to <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-12-28/iran-orders-crypto-mining-ban-to-save-power-amid-winter-crunch" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Iran</a> and <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/01/12/1066589/bitcoin-mining-boom-kazakhstan/" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">Kazakhstan</a>, which also enacted restrictions.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">And shipping pallets piled high with Bitcoin-mining computers <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/cryptocurrency-companies-are-leaving-china-in-great-mining-migration-11629624602" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">started arriving in America</a>, where some states welcomed them in.</p><h2 class="css-9ycfei eoo0vm40" id="link-1f20658f">The Land of Coal and Oil</h2></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><figure class="sizeFull css-7rkrfl" aria-label="media" role="group" data-testid="VideoBlock"><div class="css-bsn42l"><span class="css-1dv1kvn">Video</span><div class="css-11kuxu4" style="width:100%;padding-bottom:56.25%;overflow:hidden"><div class="css-122y91a"><img src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/03/28/autossell/dakota-poster/dakota-poster-videoSixteenByNine1050.jpg" class="css-gvnats"/><video data-testid="cinemagraph" src="https://vp.nyt.com/video/2023/03/28/107281_1_bitcoin-north-dakota_wg_720p.mp4" class="cinemagraph_video css-gvnats" muted="" loop="" autoplay="" playsinline=""></video></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-y5g5d7 e1maroi60"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Applied Digital Bitcoin mine in Jamestown, N.D.</span><span class="css-cch8ym"><span class="css-1dv1kvn">Credit</span><span class="css-1u46b97 e1z0qqy90"><span class="css-1ly73wi e1tej78p0">Credit...</span><span>Video by Tim Wallace</span></span></span></figcaption></figure></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Just north of Jamestown, N.D., the land is flat, trees are scarce and, in winter, snow drifts can easily top 10 feet. Even when brisk prairie winds blow, the shrill whine of the fans within Applied Digital’s Bitcoin mine can be heard a half-mile away.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">They are working to cool more than 30,000 computers, stacked two stories high, stretching for hundreds of feet alongside signs that read “Danger — High Voltage.” The radiating heat melts the snow on one side of each of the operation’s eight buildings.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><figure class="sizeMedium layoutVertical verticalVideo css-7rkrfl" aria-label="media" role="group" data-testid="VideoBlock"><div class="css-bsn42l"><span class="css-1dv1kvn">Video</span><div><div class="css-n27z15" style="padding-bottom:177.77777777777777%"><div class="css-mm3pwi"></div><div class="css-1cueeje" style="padding-bottom:177.77777777777777%;transition:opacity 300ms ease-in-out"><div class="css-1ihorw"><img src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2023/03/29/autossell/mine-interior/mine-interior-superJumbo.jpg" alt="Video player loading"/></div><div class="css-ew1078"><div class="css-ptry2i"><div></div><div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><figcaption class="css-y5g5d7 e1maroi60"><span class="css-jevhma e13ogyst0">Applied Digital Bitcoin mine in Jamestown, N.D.</span></figcaption></figure></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The mine has 33 employees and uses nearly 10 times as much electricity as all the homes in the 16,000-person town. It is one of three mines in the state that together consume nearly as much power as every home in North Dakota.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Few other states have been as welcoming to Bitcoin companies. In October 2021, Gov. Doug Burgum presented an <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.governor.nd.gov/news/governors-choice-awards-recognize-outstanding-economic-development-north-dakota-0" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">economic development award</a> to local officials and a power provider for bringing a mine to Grand Forks. Months later, he announced the development of a $1.9 billion Bitcoin operation in Williston. And last spring, he <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.jamestownsun.com/news/burgum-touts-applied-blockchains-facility-states-energy-policies" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">flipped</a> a switch at the Jamestown mine’s ribbon-cutting ceremony.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The Bitcoin operations’ effect on the state’s economy is simple, said Josh Teigen, the commerce commissioner: “They are propping up our fossil fuel industry, and that’s exactly what we want.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">North Dakota has an abundance of lignite, a type of coal primarily used to generate electricity. Mr. Teigen said the state hopes to ultimately<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>capture the carbon from fossil fuel power plants and store it underground, reducing emissions while keeping the coal industry alive<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">.</strong></p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The state also has a large amount of wind power, which is what attracted<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"> </strong>Applied Digital, said Wes Cummins, its chief executive.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">His company is not alone. Many Bitcoin businesses promote their ability to operate in rural areas where renewable energy is abundant.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">But those claims have hit a hard reality: A vast majority of that renewable energy would be used even in the absence of the mines, so fossil fuel plants almost always need to produce additional electricity as a result of their operations.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">For example, the Jamestown mine’s power demand causes coal or natural gas energy providers to generate electricity more than 90 percent of the time, WattTime found.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Using a technique known as <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.watttime.org/app/uploads/2022/10/WattTime-MOER-modeling-20221004.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">marginal emissions analysis</a>, WattTime examined each mine’s location and power use, identified which types of power plants had generated the additional energy needed, and estimated the resulting pollution. That method, and WattTime in particular, were recommended in a report by the Crypto Climate Accord, an initiative to reduce the industry’s carbon footprint supported by more than 200 cryptocurrency companies.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The analysis found that the 34 mines’ power use was causing nearly 16.4 million tons of carbon pollution each year.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><section id="bitcoin-table-embed" data-id="100000008794733" data-source-id="100000008794733" class="interactive-content interactive-size-scoop css-1fwl6kh"><div class="css-17ih8de interactive-body" data-sourceid="100000008794733">

</div></section></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">This proved true in upstate New York, where a gas-powered plant reopened and now powers a Bitcoin mine. Three other large operations are run by companies that also own the fossil fuel plants where they operate, including two burning waste coal in Pennsylvania.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Some of the Bitcoin companies that WattTime found to be causing the most pollution have held themselves out as supporting renewables.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">For example, Riot Platforms’ chief executive described Bitcoin mining as “uniquely beneficial and supportive of renewable energy.” Ninety-six percent of the power demand added by the company’s mine was met by fossil fuels, the WattTime analysis showed.</p><h2 class="css-9ycfei eoo0vm40" id="link-70667f57">Bitcoin Miners’ Power Play</h2><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Mining Bitcoin produces steady revenue, but using so much electricity can also be a business model.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Moments of extreme weather provide especially stark examples. Take June 23, 2022 — the eighth straight day of near-100-degree temperatures around Austin, which allowed Riot Platforms to demonstrate several ways they can turn electricity into money.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Like many industrial buyers, the company had prepurchased its power at a fraction of the price available to residential customers. Riot’s mine runs at 450 megawatts — the largest in the country.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Each day that June, its computers’ guesses were winning Bitcoin worth an average of about<strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10"><em class="css-2fg4z9 e1gzwzxm0"> </em></strong>$342,000. But the company had two additional ways to improve its profit margins.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">First, it had signed up for the Responsive Reserve Service, a Texas power grid program that offers a way to quickly reduce strain if the grid becomes overloaded, acting as insurance against blackouts. The program pays miners, and other companies, for promising to stop using electricity upon request. In reality, they are rarely asked to shut down, but are still paid for making the pledge.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div></div><div></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">From midnight to nearly 4 p.m. on June 23, Riot earned more than $42,000 from the program while continuing to mine Bitcoin. (Overall in 2022, Riot made nearly $9.3 million from participating in the program nearly 85 percent of the time, the data shows, though the grid operator asked companies to actually lower their use for about 3.5 hours.)</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Around that time, the company switched to the second technique: avoiding fees that Texas charges to maintain and strengthen the power grid. It did so by briefly shutting off almost completely.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">To incentivize big customers to conserve electricity, those fees are based on how much electricity they use during several peak summer moments. Riot reduced its power use by more than 99 percent.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">By 6:30 p.m., the company had resumed mining. If Riot had been fully operating all day, it would have incurred an estimated $5.5 million in fees — costs that are largely made up by other Texans. Over the course of the year, this saved Riot more than $27 million in potential fees.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">The company’s actions were described in data published by the Texas grid operator, the Electric Reliability Council of Texas, or ERCOT. Though the records refer to power suppliers by pseudonyms, The Times was able to identify six of the 10 Texas operations in the data.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">One final mechanism lets some companies make extra money when electricity prices spike: They can stop mining and resell electricity to other customers. That earned Riot roughly $18 million last year.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">From Bitcoin mining, the company earned $156.9 million last year.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Five of the six Texas mines in the power grid data participate in the Responsive Reserve program. All six chose to turn off nearly every time fees were assessed in 2022, saving an estimated $62 million in fees.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">When asked whether Bitcoin companies are disproportionately able to take advantage of both programs, ERCOT said in a statement that it “does not discriminate based on the type or activity” of the companies that sign up.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div><section id="core-scientific-denton-card" data-id="100000008839999" data-source-id="100000008839999" class="interactive-content interactive-size-scoop css-1fwl6kh"><div class="css-17ih8de interactive-body" data-sourceid="100000008839999">

</div></section></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“It’s a massive financial burden to Texans,” said Ben Hertz-Shargel, who leads grid-related research at Wood Mackenzie, and was part of the team that conducted the market-based simulation for The Times based on historical ERCOT data. Because of how the Texas market operates, the increases are steepest for residential customers, said Mr. Hertz-Shargel, who has previously criticized Bitcoin’s dependence on electricity as “inessential.”</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Others say increased prices will incentivize the development of cheaper types of power generation.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">“Expanding Texas generation is crucial, and allowing different energy sources to compete in the market will help drive down prices,” said Gideon Powell, chief executive at Cholla, an energy exploration company in Texas that is developing Bitcoin mines.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">As of last month, ERCOT had approved plans to connect an additional <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://www.ercot.com/files/docs/2023/03/20/LLI%20Queue%20Status%20Update%20-%202023-03-20.pdf" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">4,000 megawatts</a> of Bitcoin operations this year, which would nearly triple their consumption in Texas.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In Congress, Democrats have called for a precise inventory of operations’ power use and resulting emissions. </div></section></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">And in Texas, the companies have powerful allies. Gov. Greg Abbott said in a <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://twitter.com/GregAbbott_TX/status/1406104291950071808" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">tweet</a> that “Texas will be the crypto leader” and <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://twitter.com/GregAbbott_TX/status/1449392437906980871" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">hosted</a> the Texas Blockchain Council at the governor’s mansion. The grid’s former interim chief executive declared himself “pro Bitcoin,” and the current vice chair of the grid’s board is a former adviser to the Texas Blockchain Council. Still, in March, three Republican state senators joined in <a class="css-yywogo" href="https://cbsaustin.com/news/local/texas-senate-bill-seeks-to-regulate-bitcoin-miners-and-their-electricity-consumption-riot-platforms-ercot-rockdale" title="" rel="noopener noreferrer" target="_blank">sponsoring a bill</a> that would restrict tax breaks for miners and place strict limits on their participation in programs like the Responsive Reserve.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In Rockdale, where two of the largest mines in the country operate just outside the city limits, the city manager, Barbara Holly, told The Times that the town used to be “a fairly wealthy little community.” She said that changed when a large industrial plant that had provided thousands of jobs closed more than a decade ago. “It just cut the legs out from under this community,” she said.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">It was the old aluminum smelter, now home to the Bitdeer mine.</p><p class="css-798hid etfikam0">Produced by <!-- -->Gray Beltran<!-- --> and <!-- -->Ege Uz<!-- -->. Additional graphics work by <!-- -->Jon Huang<!-- -->. Reporting was contributed by Mr. Huang, <!-- -->Zach Levitt<!-- -->, <!-- -->Aimee Ortiz<!-- -->, <!-- -->Julie Tate<!-- --> and <!-- -->Tim Wallace<!-- -->.</p><p class="css-798hid etfikam0">Audio produced by <!-- -->Jack D’Isidoro<!-- -->.</p><hr class="css-7ad88g e1mu4ftr0"/><p class="css-798hid etfikam0"><strong class="css-8qgvsz ebyp5n10">About the Analysis</strong></p><p class="css-798hid etfikam0">The Times identified large Bitcoin mines by reviewing public statements, news articles and financial disclosures, then used satellite imagery and land records to determine each operation’s precise location and the specific part of the U.S. electric grid it connects to. Operations can grow and shrink often; The Times’s analysis reflects information available as of March 9. Companies confirmed the operating levels of 21 mines, declined to confirm specific numbers for five others and did not respond to repeated requests regarding the remaining eight. WattTime’s calculations were based on each mine operating 95 percent of the time — a commonly accepted industry figure — except in the case of two companies that provided alternate numbers: Coinmint and TeraWulf. WattTime’s calculations also assumed miners’ offline hours were during the highest-polluting times.</p><p class="css-798hid etfikam0">Wood Mackenzie produced annual estimates based on locations and power levels and accounted for miners shutting down during the most expensive moments.</p><p class="css-798hid etfikam0">To calculate the number of households that collectively consume as much electricity as certain mines, The Times used 2020 census data on occupied housing units from the University of Minnesota’s IPUMS NHGIS system and 2021 average national and state-level household electricity consumption rates from the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Numbers are rounded to the nearest thousand.</p><p class="css-798hid etfikam0">On maps comparing energy consumption of mines to nearby communities, households were placed randomly within census blocks. Regions on the Texas map were based on the state grid operator’s list of counties within each of the grid’s weather zones.</p><hr class="css-7ad88g e1mu4ftr0"/></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" Winter Storm Uri had knocked out power plants across the state, leaving tens of thousands of homes in icy darkness. By the end of Feb. 14, 2021, nearly 40 people had died, some from the freezing cold.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":0,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Meanwhile, in the husk of a onetime aluminum smelting plant an hour outside of Austin, row upon row of computers were using enough electricity to power about 6,500 homes as they raced to earn Bitcoin, the world’s largest cryptocurrency.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":1,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The computers were performing trillions of calculations per second, hunting for an elusive combination of numbers that Bitcoin’s algorithm would accept. About every 10 minutes, a computer somewhere guesses correctly and wins a small number of Bitcoins worth, in recent weeks, about $170,000. Anyone can try, but to make a business of it can require as much electricity as a small city.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":2,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"In Texas, the computers kept running until just after midnight. Then the state’s power grid operator ordered them shut off, under an agreement that allowed it to do so if the system was about to fail. In return, it began paying the Bitcoin company, Bitdeer, an average of $175,000 an hour to keep the computers offline. Over the next four days, Bitdeer would make more than $18 million for not operating, from fees ultimately paid by Texans who had endured the storm.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":3,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The New York Times has identified 34 such large-scale operations, known as Bitcoin mines, in the United States, all putting immense pressure on the power grid and most finding novel ways to profit from doing so. Their operations can create costs — including higher electricity bills and enormous carbon pollution — for everyone around them, most of whom have nothing to do with Bitcoin.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":4,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Until June 2021, most Bitcoin mining was in China. Then it drove out Bitcoin operations, at least for a time, citing their power use among other reasons. The United States quickly became the industry’s global leader.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":5,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Since then, precisely how much electricity Bitcoin mines are using in America and their effect on energy markets and the environment have been unclear. The Times, using both public and confidential records as well as the results of studies it commissioned, put the most comprehensive estimates to date on the largest operations’ power use and the ripple effects of their voracious demand.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":6,"bad":true},{"__typename":"InteractiveBlock","media":{"__typename":"EmbeddedInteractive","id":"RW1iZWRkZWRJbnRlcmFjdGl2ZTpueXQ6Ly9lbWJlZGRlZGludGVyYWN0aXZlLzUyMzZjZmMzLWEwNmEtNWRkMC04MGQ3LTUwYjQ3YmFlMGFjOA==","appName":"","storyFormat":null,"slug":"households-energy-map","html":"\u003Cscript drone image by Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times (Rockdale, Texas)","uri":"nyt:\u002F\u002Fembeddedinteractive\u002F5236cfc3-a06a-5dd0-80d7-50b47bae0ac8","promotionalMedia":null}},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":7,"bad":true},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"It is as if another New York City’s worth of residences were now drawing on the nation’s power supply, The Times found.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":8,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"In some areas, this has led prices to surge. In Texas, where 10 of the 34 mines are connected to the state’s grid, the increased demand has caused electric bills for power customers to rise nearly 5 percent, or $1.8 billion per year, according to a simulation performed for The Times by the energy research and consulting firm Wood Mackenzie.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":9,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The additional power use across the country also causes as much carbon pollution as adding 3.5 million gas-powered cars to America’s roads, according to an analysis by WattTime, a nonprofit tech company. Many of the Bitcoin operations promote themselves as environmentally friendly and set up in areas rich with renewable energy, but their power needs are far too great to be satisfied by those sources alone. As a result, they have become a boon for the fossil fuel industry: WattTime found that coal and natural gas plants kick in to meet 85 percent of the demand these Bitcoin operations add to their grids.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":10,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Their massive energy consumption combined with their ability to shut off almost instantly allows some companies to save money and make money by deftly pulling the levers of U.S. power markets. They can avoid fees charged during peak demand, resell their electricity at a premium when prices spike and even be paid for offering to turn off. Other major energy users, like factories and hospitals, cannot reduce their power use as routinely or dramatically without severe consequences.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":true,"index":11,"bad":false},{"__typename":"UnstructuredBlock","dataType":"ExperimentalBlock_AdHint","data":"{\"type\":\"ExperimentalBlock_AdHint\",\"content\":[],\"formats\":[],\"media\":[],\"isUnstructured\":true}","mediaRefs":[]},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"In some states, notably New York, Pennsylvania and Texas, Bitcoin operators’ revenue can ultimately come from other power customers. The clearest example is Texas, where Bitcoin companies are paid by the grid operator for promising to quickly power down if necessary to prevent blackouts. In practice, they rarely are asked to shut down and instead earn additional money while doing exactly what they would have been doing anyway: seeking Bitcoin. Five operations have collectively made at least $60 million from that program since 2020, records show.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":12,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Several of the companies are being paid through these agreements a majority of the time they operate. Most years, they are asked to turn off for only a few hours, at which point they are paid even more.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":13,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The windfall for Bitdeer during Winter Storm Uri came through this program, in exchange for a fraction of the power it typically used. The company did not respond to requests for comment. Another Bitcoin company made tens of millions of dollars reselling electricity during the storm — and ultimately stands to earn as much as $125 million — according to its financial filings, which were previously reported by the ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Tech Transparency Project","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Ftechtransparencyproject.cdn.prismic.io\u002Ftechtransparencyproject\u002F369c5690-7e26-427a-9116-26f46616b45d_Crypto+Texas+Report.pdf","title":""}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":". A third company ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"told investors","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.sec.gov\u002FArchives\u002Fedgar\u002Fdata\u002F1886015\u002F000121390022007894\u002Ffs12022a4_agoradigitalhold.htm","title":""}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":" that another natural disaster like Uri could be a significant business opportunity.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":14,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“Ironically, when people are paying the most for their power, or losing it altogether, the miners are making money selling energy back to Texans at rates 100 times what they paid,” said Ed Hirs, who teaches energy economics at the University of Houston and has been critical of the industry.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":15,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"In interviews and statements, many of the companies said they were no different from other large power users except for their willingness to shut off quickly to benefit the grid. Several objected to the method The Times and WattTime used to estimate their emissions, which calculated the pollution caused by the additional power generated to satisfy the mines’ demand, showing it to overwhelmingly come from fossil fuels.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":16,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The companies said this method held them to an unfair standard.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“The analysis cited could be used to attack any industry that consumes power,” said David Fogel, the chief executive of Coinmint, which operates in upstate New York. “I think the entire notion of singling out specific industries like this is unfair.”","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":17,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"But WattTime’s method is the one many energy and climate experts recommend for measuring the environmental effects of increased power use by any industry, particularly one that grows so large so suddenly.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":true,"index":18,"bad":false},{"__typename":"UnstructuredBlock","dataType":"ExperimentalBlock_AdHint","data":"{\"type\":\"ExperimentalBlock_AdHint\",\"content\":[],\"formats\":[],\"media\":[],\"isUnstructured\":true}","mediaRefs":[]},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Some harm.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":19,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"A ","formats":[]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"letter","formats":[{"__typename":"LinkFormat","url":"https:\u002F\u002Fbitcoinminingcouncil.com\u002Fwp-content\u002Fuploads\u002F2022\u002F05\u002FBitcoin_Letter_to_the_Environmental_Protection_Agency.pdf","title":""}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":" to the Environmental Protection Agency, signed by many of the biggest companies, said their operations “released” no pollutants. “Bitcoin miners have no emissions whatsoever,” it said. “Associated generation.”","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":20,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Nic ","formats":[{"__typename":"ItalicFormat","type":null},{"__typename":"BoldFormat","type":null}]},{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"prominent Bitcoin advocate who told The Times he was the letter’s primary author, said he was playing a “language game” when he wrote that Bitcoin mining has no emissions. At the time, he said, he felt the industry was being unfairly singled out.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":21,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“Maybe the more sincere point is like, we’re already fully aware of the emissions associated with utilities generating grid power,” he said.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":22,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Many academics who study the energy industry said Bitcoin mining was undoubtedly having significant environmental effects.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":23,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“They’re adding hundreds of megawatts of new demand when we already face the need to rapidly cut fossil power,” said Jesse Jenkins, a Princeton professor who studies electrical grid emissions.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":24,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"“If you care about climate change,” he added, “then that’s a problem.”","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Heading2Block","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Flooding Into America","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Bitcoin, conceived in 2008, introduced most of the world to the concept of cryptocurrencies. Take June 23, 2022 — the eighth straight day of near-100-degree temperatures around Austin, which allowed Riot Platforms to demonstrate several ways they can turn electricity into money.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":63,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Like many industrial buyers, the company had prepurchased its power at a fraction of the price available to residential customers. But the company had two additional ways to improve its profit margins.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":65,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"First, it had signed up for the Responsive Reserve Service, a Texas power grid program that offers a way to quickly reduce strain if the grid becomes overloaded, acting as insurance against blackouts. The program pays miners, and other companies, for promising to stop using electricity upon request. In reality, they are rarely asked to shut down, but are still paid for making the pledge.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":true,"adsMobileHoldout":true,"adsMobile":true,"adsDesktop":true,"index":66,"bad":false},{"__typename":"UnstructuredBlock","dataType":"ExperimentalBlock_AdHint","data":"{\"type\":\"ExperimentalBlock_AdHint\",\"content\":[],\"formats\":[],\"media\":[],\"isUnstructured\":true}","mediaRefs":[]},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"From midnight to nearly 4 p.m. on June 23, Riot earned more than $42,000 from the program while continuing to mine Bitcoin. (Overall in 2022, Riot made nearly $9.3 million from participating in the program nearly 85 percent of the time, the data shows, though the grid operator asked companies to actually lower their use for about 3.5 hours.)","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":67,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Around that time, the company switched to the second technique: avoiding fees that Texas charges to maintain and strengthen the power grid. It did so by briefly shutting off almost completely.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":68,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"To incentivize big customers to conserve electricity, those fees are based on how much electricity they use during several peak summer moments. Riot reduced its power use by more than 99 percent.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":69,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"By 6:30 p.m., the company had resumed mining. If Riot had been fully operating all day, it would have incurred an estimated $5.5 million in fees — costs that are largely made up by other Texans. Over the course of the year, this saved Riot more than $27 million in potential fees.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":70,"bad":false},{"__typename":"ParagraphBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"The company’s actions were described in data published by the Texas grid operator, the Electric Reliability Council of Texas, or ERCOT. Operations can grow and shrink often; The Times’s analysis reflects information available as of March 9. Companies confirmed the operating levels of 21 mines, declined to confirm specific numbers for five others and did not respond to repeated requests regarding the remaining eight. WattTime’s calculations were based on each mine operating 95 percent of the time — a commonly accepted industry figure — except in the case of two companies that provided alternate numbers: Coinmint and TeraWulf. WattTime’s calculations also assumed miners’ offline hours were during the highest-polluting times.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"DetailBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"Wood Mackenzie produced annual estimates based on locations and power levels and accounted for miners shutting down during the most expensive moments.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"DetailBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"To calculate the number of households that collectively consume as much electricity as certain mines, The Times used 2020 census data on occupied housing units from the University of Minnesota’s IPUMS NHGIS system and 2021 average national and state-level household electricity consumption rates from the U.S. Energy Information Administration. Numbers are rounded to the nearest thousand.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"DetailBlock","textAlign":"LEFT","content":[{"__typename":"TextInline","text":"On maps comparing energy consumption of mines to nearby communities, households were placed randomly within census blocks. Regions on the Texas map were based on the state grid operator’s list of counties within each of the grid’s weather zones.","formats":[]}]},{"__typename":"Dropzone","adsDesktopHoldout":false,"adsMobileHoldout":false,"adsMobile":false,"adsDesktop":false,"index":92,"bad":false},{"__typename":"RuleBlock","type":null}],"__typename":"DocumentBlock"},"storyFormat":null,"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.nytimes.com\u002F2023\u002F04\u002F09\u002Fbusiness\u002Fbitcoin-mining-electricity-pollution.html","adTargetingParams":[{"key":"als_test","value":"1682341934003","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"prop","value":"nyt","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"plat","value":"web","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"edn","value":"us","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"brandsensitive","value":"false","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"per","value":"","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"org","value":"","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"geo","value":"texas,northdakota,unitedstates","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"des","value":"bitcoincurrency,electriclightandpower,pricesfaresfeesandrates,computersandtheinternet,greenhousegasemissions,globalwarming,powerfailuresandblackouts,audioneutralinformative","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"spon","value":"","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"auth","value":"gabrieljxdance,timwallace,zachlevitt","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"col","value":"","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"coll","value":"usnews,technology,climateandenvironment,business,emergingtech,reporterreads","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"artlen","value":"xlong","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"ledemedsz","value":"none","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"gui","value":"","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"template","value":"article","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"typ","value":"art","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"section","value":"business","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"si_section","value":"business","__typename":"AdTargetingParam"},{"key":"id","value":"100000008452470","_ oembed.title: The Real-World Costs of the Digital Race for Bitcoin
oembed.summary: Bitcoin mines cash in on electricity — by devouring it, selling it, even turning it off — and they cause immense pollution. In many cases, the public pays a price.
oembed.author_name: By Gabriel J.X. Dance, Tim Wallace and Zach Levitt
oembed.html: <iframe src="https://www.nytimes.com/svc/oembed/html/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2023%2F04%2F09%2Fbusiness%2Fbitcoin-mining-electricity-pollution.html" scrolling="no" frameborder="0" allowtransparency="true" title="The Real-World Costs of the Digital Race for Bitcoin" style="border:none;max-width:500px;min-width:300px;min-height:550px;display:block;width:100%;"></iframe>
oembed.thumbnail_credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times

readabilityObject.title: The Real-World Costs of the Digital Race for Bitcoin
readabilityObject.content:
Bitcoin mines cash in on electricity — by devouring it, selling it, even turning it off — and they cause immense pollution. In many cases, the public pays a price.

The Bitdeer mine in Rockdale, Texas.Credit...Video by Jordan Vonderhaar

Gabriel J.X. Dance

Graphics by Tim Wallace and Zach Levitt

Gabriel J.X. Dance traveled to Texas and North Dakota, interviewed Bitcoin miners, energy experts, scientists and politicians and analyzed thousands of records detailing mining operations for this story. Send tips.

  • Published April 9, 2023Updated April 11, 2023

Texas was gasping for electricity. Winter Storm Uri had knocked out power plants across the state, leaving tens of thousands of homes in icy darkness. By the end of Feb. 14, 2021, nearly 40 people had died, some from the freezing cold.

Meanwhile, in the husk of a onetime aluminum smelting plant an hour outside of Austin, row upon row of computers were using enough electricity to power about 6,500 homes as they raced to earn Bitcoin, the world’s largest cryptocurrency.

The computers were performing trillions of calculations per second, hunting for an elusive combination of numbers that Bitcoin’s algorithm would accept. About every 10 minutes, a computer somewhere guesses correctly and wins a small number of Bitcoins worth, in recent weeks, about $170,000. Anyone can try, but to make a business of it can require as much electricity as a small city.

In Texas, the computers kept running until just after midnight. Then the state’s power grid operator ordered them shut off, under an agreement that allowed it to do so if the system was about to fail. In return, it began paying the Bitcoin company, Bitdeer, an average of $175,000 an hour to keep the computers offline. Over the next four days, Bitdeer would make more than $18 million for not operating, from fees ultimately paid by Texans who had endured the storm.

The New York Times has identified 34 such large-scale operations, known as Bitcoin mines, in the United States, all putting immense pressure on the power grid and most finding novel ways to profit from doing so. Their operations can create costs — including higher electricity bills and enormous carbon pollution — for everyone around them, most of whom have nothing to do with Bitcoin.

Until June 2021, most Bitcoin mining was in China. Then it drove out Bitcoin operations, at least for a time, citing their power use among other reasons. The United States quickly became the industry’s global leader.

Since then, precisely how much electricity Bitcoin mines are using in America and their effect on energy markets and the environment have been unclear. The Times, using both public and confidential records as well as the results of studies it commissioned, put the most comprehensive estimates to date on the largest operations’ power use and the ripple effects of their voracious demand.

It is as if another New York City’s worth of residences were now drawing on the nation’s power supply, The Times found.

In some areas, this has led prices to surge. In Texas, where 10 of the 34 mines are connected to the state’s grid, the increased demand has caused electric bills for power customers to rise nearly 5 percent, or $1.8 billion per year, according to a simulation performed for The Times by the energy research and consulting firm Wood Mackenzie.

The additional power use across the country also causes as much carbon pollution as adding 3.5 million gas-powered cars to America’s roads, according to an analysis by WattTime, a nonprofit tech company. Many of the Bitcoin operations promote themselves as environmentally friendly and set up in areas rich with renewable energy, but their power needs are far too great to be satisfied by those sources alone. As a result, they have become a boon for the fossil fuel industry: WattTime found that coal and natural gas plants kick in to meet 85 percent of the demand these Bitcoin operations add to their grids.

Their massive energy consumption combined with their ability to shut off almost instantly allows some companies to save money and make money by deftly pulling the levers of U.S. power markets. They can avoid fees charged during peak demand, resell their electricity at a premium when prices spike and even be paid for offering to turn off. Other major energy users, like factories and hospitals, cannot reduce their power use as routinely or dramatically without severe consequences.

In some states, notably New York, Pennsylvania and Texas, Bitcoin operators’ revenue can ultimately come from other power customers. The clearest example is Texas, where Bitcoin companies are paid by the grid operator for promising to quickly power down if necessary to prevent blackouts. In practice, they rarely are asked to shut down and instead earn additional money while doing exactly what they would have been doing anyway: seeking Bitcoin. Five operations have collectively made at least $60 million from that program since 2020, records show.

Several of the companies are being paid through these agreements a majority of the time they operate. Most years, they are asked to turn off for only a few hours, at which point they are paid even more.

The windfall for Bitdeer during Winter Storm Uri came through this program, in exchange for a fraction of the power it typically used. The company did not respond to requests for comment. Another Bitcoin company made tens of millions of dollars reselling electricity during the storm — and ultimately stands to earn as much as $125 million — according to its financial filings, which were previously reported by the Tech Transparency Project. A third company told investors that another natural disaster like Uri could be a significant business opportunity.

“Ironically, when people are paying the most for their power, or losing it altogether, the miners are making money selling energy back to Texans at rates 100 times what they paid,” said Ed Hirs, who teaches energy economics at the University of Houston and has been critical of the industry.

In interviews and statements, many of the companies said they were no different from other large power users except for their willingness to shut off quickly to benefit the grid. Several objected to the method The Times and WattTime used to estimate their emissions, which calculated the pollution caused by the additional power generated to satisfy the mines’ demand, showing it to overwhelmingly come from fossil fuels.

The companies said this method held them to an unfair standard.

“The analysis cited could be used to attack any industry that consumes power,” said David Fogel, the chief executive of Coinmint, which operates in upstate New York. “I think the entire notion of singling out specific industries like this is unfair.”

But WattTime’s method is the one many energy and climate experts recommend for measuring the environmental effects of increased power use by any industry, particularly one that grows so large so suddenly.

Some in the industry have pushed back against suggestions that it is directly responsible for any environmental harm.

A May 2022 letter to the Environmental Protection Agency, signed by many of the biggest companies, said their operations “released” no pollutants. “Bitcoin miners have no emissions whatsoever,” it said. “Associated emissions are a function of electricity generation.”

Nic Carter, a partner at a crypto-focused venture capital firm and a prominent Bitcoin advocate who told The Times he was the letter’s primary author, said he was playing a “language game” when he wrote that Bitcoin mining has no emissions. At the time, he said, he felt the industry was being unfairly singled out.

“Maybe the more sincere point is like, we’re already fully aware of the emissions associated with utilities generating grid power,” he said.

Many academics who study the energy industry said Bitcoin mining was undoubtedly having significant environmental effects.

“They’re adding hundreds of megawatts of new demand when we already face the need to rapidly cut fossil power,” said Jesse Jenkins, a Princeton professor who studies electrical grid emissions.

“If you care about climate change,” he added, “then that’s a problem.”

Flooding Into America

Bitcoin, conceived in 2008, introduced most of the world to the concept of cryptocurrencies. Instead of trusting banks to track the value of accounts, the system publishes transactions on a public ledger called a blockchain. Proponents said that cutting out middlemen would free people from financial institutions, government oversight and fees.

So-called mining is a fundamental part of the system: When a computer guesses correctly, it updates the ledger and collects six and a quarter new Bitcoins. Then the guessing game begins again.

Initially, hobbyists could win with personal computers, but as the value of each Bitcoin soared — from under $1,000 in 2017 to above $60,000 in 2021 — mining increasingly became an industrial endeavor. (The price has since dropped and, as of publication, was roughly $28,000.)

The only way for miners to better their odds is to add computing power, which requires more electricity. But as the number of guesses increases, the algorithm makes the game more difficult. This has created an energy arms race.

The mines’ scale can draw gasps from people in the power industry. A one-megawatt mine consumes more energy each day than a typical U.S. home does in two years. The electricity coursing through a 100-megawatt operation at a given moment could power about half the homes in Cleveland, according to federal data.

Aspects of the industry have previously been reported in news articles and government and nonprofit white papers, including broad estimates of the environmental effects. But The Times cross-referenced financial disclosures, land records and satellite imagery to create the first national accounting of the biggest operations. The analysis includes mines operating at approximately 40 megawatts or higher, although dozens more exist below that threshold.

Of course, other industries, including metals and plastics manufacturing, also require large amounts of electricity, causing pollution and raising power prices. But Bitcoin mines bring significantly fewer jobs, often employing only a few dozen people once construction is complete, and spur less local economic development.

Their financial benefit flows almost exclusively to their owners and operators. In 2021, the year Bitcoin’s price peaked, 20 executives at five publicly traded Bitcoin companies together received nearly $16 million in salary and over $630 million in stock options, records show.

The industry has been less profitable since then, as Bitcoin’s value has dropped and electricity prices have climbed. Two of the largest United States-based companies have filed for bankruptcy. Still, new mines continue to open across the country

There are ways to operate a cryptocurrency using far less electricity. Last year, Ethereum, the second-most-popular cryptocurrency, reduced the electricity needed to power the network by more than 99 percent by switching its algorithm. Now it rewards people and trusts them to update the ledger because they are willing to put up their own money as collateral, not because they have spent money to power guessing computers, as Bitcoin does.

But Bitcoin advocates oppose changing their algorithm, saying that it has proved resistant to attacks for longer and at a greater scale than any other approach. In practice, they say, the more computers making guesses, the safer the network.

Ninety-two percent of the power demand of the Genesis Digital Assets mine in Pyote, Texas, is met by fossil fuel plants, causing 546,000 tons of carbon pollution each year.

Aerial view showing ten large buildings next to rows of smaller structures surrounded by dirt and sparse plants.

As Bitcoin mining has spread, countries around the world have found that operations strained their power grids. In 2019, China declared the industry “undesirable” and banned it in 2021. Many operations moved to Iran and Kazakhstan, which also enacted restrictions.

And shipping pallets piled high with Bitcoin-mining computers started arriving in America, where some states welcomed them in.

The Land of Coal and Oil

Just north of Jamestown, N.D., the land is flat, trees are scarce and, in winter, snow drifts can easily top 10 feet. Even when brisk prairie winds blow, the shrill whine of the fans within Applied Digital’s Bitcoin mine can be heard a half-mile away.

They are working to cool more than 30,000 computers, stacked two stories high, stretching for hundreds of feet alongside signs that read “Danger — High Voltage.” The radiating heat melts the snow on one side of each of the operation’s eight buildings.

The mine has 33 employees and uses nearly 10 times as much electricity as all the homes in the 16,000-person town. It is one of three mines in the state that together consume nearly as much power as every home in North Dakota.

Few other states have been as welcoming to Bitcoin companies. In October 2021, Gov. Doug Burgum presented an economic development award to local officials and a power provider for bringing a mine to Grand Forks. Months later, he announced the development of a $1.9 billion Bitcoin operation in Williston. And last spring, he flipped a switch at the Jamestown mine’s ribbon-cutting ceremony.

The Bitcoin operations’ effect on the state’s economy is simple, said Josh Teigen, the commerce commissioner: “They are propping up our fossil fuel industry, and that’s exactly what we want.”

North Dakota has an abundance of lignite, a type of coal primarily used to generate electricity. Mr. Teigen said the state hopes to ultimately capture the carbon from fossil fuel power plants and store it underground, reducing emissions while keeping the coal industry alive.

The state also has a large amount of wind power, which is what attracted Applied Digital, said Wes Cummins, its chief executive.

His company is not alone. Many Bitcoin businesses promote their ability to operate in rural areas where renewable energy is abundant.

But those claims have hit a hard reality: A vast majority of that renewable energy would be used even in the absence of the mines, so fossil fuel plants almost always need to produce additional electricity as a result of their operations.

For example, the Jamestown mine’s power demand causes coal or natural gas energy providers to generate electricity more than 90 percent of the time, WattTime found.

Using a technique known as marginal emissions analysis, WattTime examined each mine’s location and power use, identified which types of power plants had generated the additional energy needed, and estimated the resulting pollution. That method, and WattTime in particular, were recommended in a report by the Crypto Climate Accord, an initiative to reduce the industry’s carbon footprint supported by more than 200 cryptocurrency companies.

The analysis found that the 34 mines’ power use was causing nearly 16.4 million tons of carbon pollution each year.

All 34 Bitcoin Mines and the Emissions They Cause

The nonprofit tech company WattTime used data provided by The Times to calculate how much of the additional electric generation the operations required was met by fossil fuel plants, and the carbon emissions that resulted.
